content.content: Key Info Delegate Address: chicagodao.eth, 0xB7771f70633C7E54E61Dd38D01c26DA0e86bE1a5 Forum: @af_UC and @sm_UC Discord: @af_UC (#5931) and @naut#1973 Email: [email protected] External Website: https://chicagodao.io/ Twitter: @chicagodao_io Delegate contract address: 0x797d63cb6709c79b9eca99d9585ea613da205156  Core Values  Serve as a rational, reliable, optimistic, unbiased and pragmatic voice within the MakerDAO community, providing value through meaningful participation in community discussions and reliable voting. Educate the University of Chicago campus and the broader University community about the Maker project + facilitate collaboration on new Maker initiatives. Help MakerDAO continue to build a sustainable and enduring community that enables the creation of a more financially free and sustainable future for all.   Delegate Statement GM! We are ChicagoDAO, a burgeoning DAO at The University of Chicago that connects the various blockchain clubs and communities on campus. As of now, we currently have representation from students in the undergraduate college, law school, and business school. We have ≈25 core contributors and ≈150 community members. We will be opening up our DAO to alumni and the broader campus over the summer and have numerous initiatives we will be working on this summer, from creating a bespoke DAO tooling platform to planning a conference in fall. Our current working groups include a Dev team, Trade/Quant Team, Internal Ops Team, Outreach Team, Research team, and an External Governance team. Our delegated tokens are managed by our External Governance team. Within this team each protocol has one to two protocol leads who keep the broader team abreast of new developments and are the central point of contact for that protocol. We meet weekly to discuss new proposals and vote in a simple, equal weighted ballot where each measure must have two-thirds of the External Governance team voting ‘yes’ to pass. Currently we have Compound and Uniswap delegated from a16z. We are excited to get started with Maker soon! Our discussions bring together students from varying backgrounds and areas of expertise. On our External Governance team we have multiple developers with experience on different blockchains, experienced traders, former and aspiring lawyers, former financial regulators, public policy analysts and more. We believe that this diversity of backgrounds allows us to have a holistic view of protocols and the potential impact of new proposals. Our key initiatives within the External Governance team are to:  Stay abreast of new developments within each protocol Actively participate in discussions and votes for all proposals Draft and put forward new proposals when appropriate Be an evangelist for the protocols and communities we are involved with  As delegates, we will be reliable stewards and work diligently to ensure the future growth and success of MakerDAO. By delegating to ChicagoDAO you are affirming the value of interdisciplinary teams and partnerships across industry and academia.  Conflicts of Interest  ChicagoDAO takes part in governance of other projects. Currently these are Uniswap and Compound  We have read and agree to abide by the Delegate Code of Conduct.  Waiver of Liability By delegating to ChicagoDAO you acknowledge that ChicagoDAO will participate in MakerDAO governance on a best efforts basis and will not be liable for damages of any form related to participation in MakerDAO, the Maker Protocol or any other activities arising from this delegation.

Key Info Name: ConsenSys Delegate Contract: 0x40f784B16b2D405eFD4E9eB7d0663398D7d886FB Delegate Address: ConsenSysGovernance.eth (0xE78658A8acfE982Fde841abb008e57e6545e38b3) Forum: @DAOstrat.C Telegram: @DAOstrat Discord: DAOStrat-ConsenSys #6952 Email: [email protected] Website: DAOs and Web3 Governance Participation | ConsenSys Meet Your Delegate Video: Link  Delegate Statement  Mission ConsenSys is devoted to supporting the growth and development of Web3. Through the development of blockchain technology, we are shaping a future world of open access, transparency, and inclusion. We are decidedly focused on improving systems, businesses, and the lives of every person in the world.  Values As an organization, we see a resounding need to ensure the growth of our ecosystem through some of the core values it is founded on. ConsenSys shares these core values when applying governance analysis, communication, and decision-making. These values include:  Decentralization Sovereign individualism Transparency Accountability Authenticity Open-source contribution   Introduction ConsenSys is recognized as an Ethereum software company. Together, we assist people and enterprises worldwide in developing innovative software, building core infrastructure, implementing innovative financial systems, and gaining access to the distributed web. As the industry matures, we believe it is important to participate in delegation to create positive outcomes on behalf of the industry. We face new challenges in DAOs. These challenges include macroeconomics, operations, and specialized finance topics. We aim to leverage our diverse resources to help streamline this dynamic landscape. Through extensive outreach and research in the ecosystem, ConsenSys understands Maker’s complexities and challenges. We are also uniquely positioned to support and protect the advancement of the protocol. Collectively, ConsenSys is here to work through every proposal, problem, success, and failure.  Voting Delegation is something that we believe is an essential part of DeFi. Our priority is the longevity of the community and protocol. Consensys leverages values first principles when analysing governance decisions. We will use the same internal core framework while evaluating proposals during our delegation.  Gov Decision Framework CN1803×772 208 KB  We also value transparent communication through all available mediums to us. We look forward to meeting you all through office hours, twitter spaces, discord calls, and more.  Delegation Team Within ConsenSys is the Cryptoeconomics team. The Cryptoeconomics team is ecosystem-facing and works in the following three main disciplines.  Tokenomics & Mechanism Design Treasury Management Web3 & DAO Participation  Consensys believes that the unique background and existing work this team has already completed allows for the management of analysis and reporting in all of our governance decision-making. The following individuals from the ConsenSys Cryptoeconomics team will lead various subject matter within our governance delegation team.   Lex Sokolin – Head Economist  Marta Piekarska – DAO Strategy Lead  David Shuttleworth – Macroeconomics & Token Engineering  Ajay Mittal – Finance & Treasury Management  Cameron O’Donnell – Governance Operations   Conclusion We look forward to being a delegate for the Maker protocol and advocating for the entire DeFi ecosystem. Sound and informed governance decision-making is embedded in our thoroughness, values, and transparency.  Delegate Code of Conduct The ConsenSys governance team agrees to the MakerDAO Delegate Code of Conduct.. IPFS CID: QmewcuegjPfUtQS7BtL28qAX41Fotz4Th5fuvp2qFGu5sy  Waiver of liability By delegating to ConsenSys, you acknowledge and agree that ConsenSys will participate on a best-efforts basis and will not be liable for any loss and/or damages related to any participation in the Maker Protocol, MakerDAO, or Maker Community.  Conflicts of Interest  Uniswap Delegation ConsenSys Product Suite MKR held in treasury (below 700 MKR) Team member DAO contributions at various levels

content.content: November Week 1 - Polls  PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Activate Liquidations for Stablecoin Vaults to Clear Bad Debt One Month Budget Extension for Strategic Happiness Core Unit    PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal - October 31, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary: The Maker Open Market Committee’s work is critical to managing risk for the protocol. This proposal includes proposed launch parameters for Compound D3M and changes to MANA-A risk parameters. Activate Compound V2 D3M with the following parameters:  <= 160M debt ceiling 10M gap 2% bar  We agree with the explanation and logic for the parameters outlined in the proposal. The following parameters are also updated  Decrease the MANA-A debt ceiling to 10 million, Increase the MANA-A stability fee to 7.5%  As outlined in the proposal, the changes to the parameters are to help incentivize the reduction of exposure to more manageable levels. Takeaway: The PPG continues to produce a quality analysis of market conditions and sound parameter changes that mitigates risk for the protocol and community.   Activate Liquidations for Stablecoin Vaults to Clear Bad Debt - October 31, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary: Activate liquidations for USDC-A & USDP-A Stablecoin Vaults to Clear Bad Debt (BD). The Vaults holding unbacked DAI originate from liquidation functions being disabled. Although the BD is no longer accruing because the stability fee – variable-rate fee continuously added to a Vault owner’s generated Dai balance – was set to 0, The vaults still sit with BD. To clear the bad debt and balance the vaults, the adjustment of unbacked DAI in the amount of ~1.3M would come from the DAOs surplus buffer.  The surplus buffer is the amount of DAI that accrues to the protocol from stability fee revenue prior to auctions being triggered. The proposal noted that the surplus buffer amounts to ~ 77,4M DAI and burning the unbacked DAO (balancing the amounts) Delta is 1.68% of the total. Counter Arguments: The vaults are not worth paying back right now unless the collateral is required to maintain the stability of the protocol. It might make sense to leverage gain from yields to slowly or at once liquidate the vaults. This is a valid argument, and we are not opposed to it. However, our position under the current operating and market conditions is to activate liquidation for the vaults. Takeaway: Although this bad debt is not a priority to clear, it should be noted that sound accounting and risk management practices take precedence within the protocol.   One Month Budget Extension for Strategic Happiness Core Unit - October 31, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: No Summary: Although we appreciate the enthusiasm of the mandate for this core unit. A decision was previously made to offboard. Swag is important as it helps to produce name recognition. But, under current market conditions, we will not be supporting this vote. As Mahatma Gandhi is quoted, “Happiness is when what you think, what you say, and what you do in harmony.” Your impact on positivity and happiness stems far past this proposal. Thank you for your hard work.  Takeaway: Under current operating and market conditions. This proposal does not make sense.

content.content: November Week 2 - Polls  Add the Compound V2 DAI Direct Deposit Module (D3M) - November 7, 2022    Add the Compound V2 DAI Direct Deposit Module (D3M) - November 7, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary: This poll allows the MakerDAO governance community to signal their support or opposition to adding the Compound V2 D3M to the Maker Protocol with the parameters below:   Maximum Debt Ceiling (line): 5 million DAI to be increased to 160 million DAI once the Protocol Engineering Core Unit are satisifed that it is safe to do so.  Target Available Debt (gap): 5 million DAI to be increased to 10 million DAI once the Protocol Engineering Core Unit are satiisfied that it is safe to increase the Maximum Debt Ceiling.  Ceiling Increase Cooldown (ttl): 12 hours.  Target Borrow Rate (bar): 2%.  A compound D3M will allow Maker to inject DAI liquidity into compound V2 producing yield. The Vault parameters have been worked through by multiple core units - outlined below - we believe an adequate amount of diligence was completed on this proposal and it is beneficial for the protocol As outlined in the voting portal, the mechanics of implementation and outcomes were assessed by the following core units to provide all necessary information:  Initial Risk Core Unit Maker Open Market Committee (MOMC) Protocol Engineering Core Unit Collateral Engineering Services Core Unit  Further Information 1. Maximum Debt Ceiling (line) - The Maximum Debt Ceiling refers to the maximum value for Debt Ceiling that the DC-IAM will allow in the given vault type. 2. Target Available Debt (gap) - The Target Available Debt parameter controls how much of a gap the DC-IAM aims to maintain between the current debt usage and the Debt Ceiling of the vault type. 3. Ceiling Increase Cooldown (ttl) - The Ceiling Increase Cooldown parameter controls how frequently the DC-IAM can increase the Debt Ceiling. 4. Target Borrow Rate (bar) - The Target Borrow Rate allows Maker Governance to set the ‘ideal’ rate for borrowing DAI on the target lending protocol. Takeaway: Maker and stakeholders continue to encourage the adoption of the Maker protocol through expansion and proven methods.

content.content: November Week 3 - Polls  [USDC-A, USDP-A, GUSD-A] Liquidation parameters & Auctions activation    [USDC-A, USDP-A, GUSD-A] Liquidation parameters & Auctions activation  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary: As outlined in this poll. The decision to move forward with clearing bad debt off the Maker DAO books is moving forward. The parameters to execute the liquidations under the following conditions:  Enable Liquidations. Use Linear Decrease for Auction Price Function (calc). Set Liquidation Penalty (chop) to 0. Set Proportional Kick Incentive (chip) to 0. Set Flat Kick Incentive (tip) to 0. Set Auction Price Multiplier (buf) to 1. Set tau to 4,320,000 seconds (72,000 minutes, or 1,200 hours). This results in an estimated 10bps drop in price every 72 minutes, or 50 days until the price reaches 0. Set Max Auction Duration (tail) to 43,200 seconds (720 minutes, or 12 hours). This implies a minimum price of 0.99. Set Max Auction Drawdown (cusp) to 0.99. Individually set the Local Liquidation Limit (ilk.hole) for the vault types as follows:  USDC-A - 20 million DAI USDP-A - 3 million DAI GUSD-A - 300,000 DAI    More Information:   Linear Decrease – An auction using a Linear Decrease Auction Price Function starts at the Auction Price Multiplier. The price will fall linearly to $0.   Auction Price Function (calc) – The Auction Price Function specifies how the collateral auction price varies over time.   Liquidity penalty – The Liquidation Penalty parameter regulates the fee vault owners must pay for inadequate collateral.   Flat Kick Incentive (tip) – Flat Kick Incentive is a DAI reward paid to keepers who trigger Maker Protocol collateral liquidation auctions.   Auction Price Multiplier (buf) – Auction Price Multiplier multiplies the auction’s beginning price.   tau – A figure in seconds that governs how long an auction takes to reach   Max Auction Duration (tail) – Maximum Auction Duration determines the maximum duration before a vault auction must restart. This value, expressed in seconds, defines when an auction must be reset.   Max Auction Drawdown (cusp) – Maximum Auction Drawdown is the maximum collateral price decline   Local Liquidation Limit (ilk.hole) – The Local Liquidation Limit determines the maximum amount of DAI debt for which collateral auctions may be engaged in a vault type (ilk).   Takeaway: Maker is progressing with clearing its bad debt, this exhibits sound accounting and risk management practices within the protocol.

November Week 4 - Polls Votes (1/2)  Proceed with Pre-Implementation Work for the Deal Outlined in MIP90 (BlockTower Liquid AAA Structured Credit and Money Market Fund) - November 21, 2022 Offboarding Parameters for renBTC-A - November 21, 2022 Add Multiple BlockTower Credit Vault Types (RWA010, RWA011, RWA012, RWA013) - November 21, 2022 Add GNO (GnosisDAO) as a new Vault Type - November 21, 2022    Proceed with Pre-Implementation Work for the Deal Outlined in MIP90 (BlockTower Liquid AAA Structured Credit and Money Market Fund) - November 21, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary:  MIP90 approves a 600MM DAI RWA vault that will leverage USDC via the PSM and acquire USD 600MM of diversified, AAA (or comparable) rated Structured Credit and Money Market Funds. All investments will be made on the open market via arms-length, competitive processes facilitated by investment banks and/or broker-dealers.  Takeaway: We Support the community moving forward with the necessary assessment to onboard MIP90. There needed to be more clarity around whether or not this was a greenlight poll. Our decision assumes this is not the final vote, but rather approves the required assessment to move forward to the “next stage” of the process.   Offboarding Parameters for renBTC-A - November 21, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary: The industry has had many impacts around the recent market events - FTX collapse. One impact, or potential impact, is REN. Alameda & FTX played a large role in REN effectively owning the protocol. To mitigate risk for the protocol, a decision is going forward to offboard renBTCA under the following parameters:   Liquidation Penalty (chop): 0%.  Flat Kick Incentive (tip): 0 DAI.  Liquidation Ratio (mat): 5000%.  Local Liquidation Limit (ilk.hole): 350,000 DAI.  We agree with the need to mitigate this risk from the users and protocol. The offboarding parameters seem logical and in line with prior actions. Takeaway: Maker is keeping up with market conditions and updating parameters as needed to avoid any fallout from recent market events.   Add Multiple BlockTower Credit Vault Types (RWA010, RWA011, RWA012, RWA013) - November 21, 2022  Vote Decision: Yes Summary: This vote is in support of a previous poll. We generally support RWA exposure in conservative financial instruments. There has been an adequate review of the application and risk education from all relevant core units seen below:  Initial Collateral Application Commercial and Legal Risk Evaluation Part 1 Commercial and legal Risk Evaluation Part 2 Collateral Engineering Services Core Unit Evaluation Protocol Engineering Core Unit Commentary  We look forward to further discussion and seeing the impact Blocktower will have on the protocol. Takeaway: Maker is moving forward with prior commitments. Please see the V Parameters outlined in summary, here.   Add GNO (GnosisDAO) as a new Vault Type - November 21, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary: This poll sets to add Gnosis as a new Vault Type within the Maker Protocol. Gnosis has a long-running reputation within the Ethereum & EVM ecosystem. While Safe has recently spun off from Gnosis, Gnosis provides a unique opportunity to engage with one of the most well-known and financially healthy DAOs in the space. As outlined in the application, Gnosis DAO has supported the Maker protocol and leveraged vaults for over a year. This is a reasonable next step forward for Gnosis and Maker. We are excited to see the ongoing developments between Gnosis & Maker, especially GNO as the use of collateral. Please see the relevant analysis below:   Risk Core Unit Evaluation.  Collateral Engineering Services Core Unit Evaluation.  Oracles Core Unit Evaluation.  Growth Core Unit Evaluation.  Takeaway: Maker is identifying high-value collateral to be used within its protocol. Although market conditions are inadequate, GNO is widely used within the Gnosis ecosystem.

content.content: November Week 4 - Polls Votes (2/2)  Ratification Poll for Immunefi Security Core Unit (IS-001) Facilitator Onboarding (MIP41c4-SP38) - November 14, 2022 Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Development and UX Core Unit (DUX-001) Budget (MIP40c3-SP82) - November 14, 2022 Ratification Poll for CoinShares Active Treasury Management (MIP86) - November 14, 2022 Ratification Poll for OUSD Decentralized Rewards (MIP87) - November 14, 2022 Ratification Poll for Modify Immunefi Security Core Unit (IS-001) Mandate (MIP39c2-SP38) - November 14, 2022 Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Immunefi Security (IS-001) Budget (MIP40c3-SP83) - November 14, 2022 Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Governance Communications Core Unit DAI Budget, COM-001 (MIP40c3-SP84) - November 14, 2022 Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Sidestream Auction Services Core Unit DAI Budget, SAS-001 (MIP40c3-SP85) - November 14, 2022 Budget Ratification Poll for Modify TechOps Core Unit DAI Budget, TECH-001 (MIP40c3-SP86) - November 14, 2022 Ratification Poll for Modify Emulated Surplus Buffer Upper Limit (MIP84c10-SP1) - November 14, 2022 Ratification Poll for Monetalis - Redwood Friesian (MIP88) - November 14, 2022 Ratification Poll for Monetalis - Arrow Andalusian (MIP89) - November 14, 2022 Budget Ratification Poll for Modify the Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling Core Unit DAI Budget, SES-001 (MIP40c3-SP87) - November 14, 2022    Ratification Poll for Immunefi Security Core Unit (IS-001) Facilitator Onboarding (MIP41c4-SP38) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: No Summary: This seeks to add Psychonaut as a facilitator for the CU Immunifi Security. It is important to note that this is a repeat vote just 7 months after a failed attempt. Although these contributions are clearly above the typical contributor, there is a documented history of negative behavior that indicates this vote is coming too soon. Also, with the changes coming from EGP, this is just not the right time. This is not a permanent no. Rather, a gap in time to rebuild. We hope to see continued support for the protocol. Thank you for all the contributions to date.   Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Development and UX Core Unit (DUX-001) Budget (MIP40c3-SP82) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Option 2: Approve reduction in budget Summary: This vote proposes modification in Dev/UX CU budget. The options are below:  Option 0: Abstain. Option 1: Approve existing budget only (Business as usual): 1,871,300 DAI Option 2: Approve reduced budget (NewBase): 1,611,420 DAI Option 3: Approve reduced budget (NewBear): 1,426,416 DAI Option 4: Reject budget.  The Core Unit recognizes the community’s active discussions regarding cost reduction and proposes budget adjustments accordingly. We agree with conservative and realistic budget streams for CUs.   Ratification Poll for CoinShares Active Treasury Management (MIP86) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: No Summary:  Under MIP86, a portion (from $100M to $500M) of the PSM’s USDCs will be managed by CoinShares, which will invest on behalf of MakerDAO the funds in various traditional financial assets according to MIP13c3-SP12 3 12.  Coinshares is a leader in the space and perfectly capable of managing funds, we enjoyed the proposal and thoroughness of the investment program. However, the macro and internal operating environments do not support this program. From a macro perspective, there is an unknown around the tradfi economy and web3 economy. Internally, the maker is preparing to embark on a long transformation journey. We welcome this proposal back when the market and operating conditions are complimentary to the program.   Ratification Poll for OUSD Decentralized Rewards (MIP87) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: No Summary: Maker to deploy 100M of USDC to OUSD and earn continuous yield while retaining full custody. OUSD rebases and dist yield (interest, fees, incentives) directly to users in the form of additional OUSD proportionally daily. 30 day trailing avg apy is 5.82%. $100M USDC from PSM into OUSD. In addition to daily yields, Origin will also give up to 3% current total supply of governance token OGV. 1% of initial OGV supply (40M) over 4 years for as long as the balance is not below $100M OUSD. Risks are in the underlying systems, including lending/AMM, stablecoin protocols and Origin protocol/governance (rely on few strategists to execute rebalancing). Lastly, the market conditions do not support this proposal. However, there will be opportunities in the future for further collaboration. We support Origin and its activities. We look forward to seeing them develop TVL and further break into more protocols.   Ratification Poll for Modify Immunefi Security Core Unit (IS-001) Mandate (MIP39c2-SP38) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Abstain Summary: This proposal is reasonable, however, fails to convey the pros and cons of the mandate change. Voting abstain as we believe this mandate change has potential, but needs to convey the change in clearer terms.   Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Immunefi Security (IS-001) Budget (MIP40c3-SP83) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Abstain Summary: Same as above. We believe the budget for this CU needs to be looked at more closely. We support ISCU and the valuable work completed.   Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Governance Communications Core Unit DAI Budget, COM-001 (MIP40c3-SP84) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Option 1: Approve budget Summary: This vote proposes modification in Gov Comms CU. The options are below:  Option 1: Approve 258,807 DAI budget streamed over six months. Option 2: Reject budget.  We believe governance is at the heart of MakerDAO and the facilitators (including gov coms ) play a huge role in maintaining governance stability for the protocol. There are adequate pros and cons (drafted by David Utro) found in this forum post: The Future for GovComms – a message encouraging voters to pass our current budget proposal    Budget Ratification Poll for Modify TechOps Core Unit DAI Budget, TECH-001 (MIP40c3-SP86) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Option 1: Approve Summary: This vote proposes modification in TechOps Core Uni budget. The options are below:  Option 1: Approve 749,685 DAI seed transfer and 2,398,988 DAI streamed over twelve months. Option 2: Reject budget.  As outlined in the proposal, the TechOps group covers a lot of ground and is needed for the end game to continue its path forward. The benefits outlined in the proposes align with the protocol.   Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Sidestream Auction Services Core Unit DAI Budget, SAS-001 (MIP40c3-SP85) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Option 3: Reject budget. Summary: This vote proposes modification in Sidestram Auction Service CU budget. The options are below:  Option 1: Approve new base budget: 433,375 DAI seed transfer and 1,040,100 DAI streamed over twelve months. Option 2: Approve new bear budget: 394,562.50 DAI seed transfer and 946,950 DAI streamed over twelve months. Option 3: Reject budget.  Priority is on founding new development around the transformation for the protocol. Although this Core Unit achieved its goals and most of the roadmap, we recognize that focus needs to be changed/modified. We reject this budget as we continue to move forward with the protocol.   Ratification Poll for Modify Emulated Surplus Buffer Upper Limit (MIP84c10-SP1) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: No Summary:  This is a proposal to increase the emulated surplus buffer upper limit to 1B DAI. This would prevent the Protocol Owned Vault Emulation (POVE) described in MIP84 7 from purchasing staked ETH assets until the surplus buffer reaches approximately 1B Dai  Whereas we agree with maintaining a liquid asset to protect the protocol, we disagree with the timing and overall parameters. We believe it is just too early to explore these parameters. Happy to revisit this at a later date.   Ratification Poll for Monetalis - Redwood Friesian (MIP88) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: No Summary:  MIP88 onboards a DAI 225M RWA vault that will acquire USDC via the PSM and acquire USD 225M of a super senior, front cash flow, AAAsf (or equivalent) rated RMBS on a bespoke basis (see Key Terms below). In addition, the transaction will be structured to provide 15% credit enhancement at closing for the super senior bonds.  Generally, RWA exposure is a positive for the protocol where adequate RM is applied. There is an unknown in the current macroeconomic market. There is a growing risk in the housing market. Because of this uncertainty, we voted no.   Ratification Poll for Monetalis - Arrow Andalusian (MIP89) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary:  “MIP89 will onboard and activate a DAI 300M RWA vault and acquire BlackRock/ishares ETF products allocated in the same manner as MIP65, and, from this asset pool, finance and deploy over 12 months a set of wholesale, senior, secure, staged, Green Economy, Lending facility focused on the UK and the EU together with Arrow Global.”    Budget Ratification Poll for Modify the Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling Core Unit DAI Budget, SES-001 (MIP40c3-SP87) - November 14, 2022  Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Option 2: Approve speedy operations platform option budget: Summary: This vote proposes modification in SES CU. The options are below:  Option 1: Approve standard option budget: 2,719,200 DAI streamed over twelve months. Option 2: Approve speedy operations platform option budget: 3,199,200 DAI streamed over twelve months. Option 3: Reject budget.  The Core Unit recognizes the community’s active discussions regarding cost reduction and proposes budget adjustments accordingly. This CU is critical to the success of the transformation the DAO previously approved. Thus, this is one of the few times in a downward market where a large budget warrants attention.

content.content: December Week 1 - Polls Votes  DAI Savings Rate Adjustment - November 28, 2022 PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal - November 28, 2022 Undertake Necessary Risk and Legal Assessments to Increase the NS-DROP Debt Ceiling to 50 Million DAI - November 28, 2022   DAI Savings Rate Adjustment - November 28, 2022 Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Increase the DAI Savings Rate to 1% Summary: This poll sets out to change the DAI Saving rate with the following options:  Leave the DAI Savings Rate unchanged at 0.01% Increase the DAI Savings Rate to 0.25% Increase the DAI Savings Rate to 0.5% Increase the DAI Savings Rate to 0.75% Increase the DAI Savings Rate to 1%  The saving rate is a critical aspect of DAI, as it relates to demand which can increase utility and liquidity. This poll is not unfounded; the EG plan calls for a 2% savings rate. It is important to note that this is being done to make MAKER more attractive to all parties. Moreover, the saving rate is manageable and can be lowered. This is an important step forward as we look to the boundaries of the system and changes being made for the endgame. We will be monitoring the impacts of this update closely.  PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal - November 28, 2022 Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary: More great work by the PPG - Open Market Committee. We believe the protocol should take necessary steps to avoid certain risks arising from market conditions. For these reasons, we agree with the changes in parameters. Some highlights are the increases in WSTETH A/B and Reducing target available Debt for WSETH, WBTC, LINK, YFI. More information: Maximum Debt Ceiling (line) - refers to the maximum value for Debt Ceiling that the DC-IAM will allow in the given vault type. Target Available Debt (gap) - Controls how much of a gap the DC-IAM aims to maintain between the current debt usage and the Debt Ceiling of the vault type. Ceiling Increase Cooldown (ttl) - Controls how frequently the Debt Ceiling can be increased by the DC-IAM. Peg Stability Module (PSM) - Allows users to swap a given collateral type directly for DAI at a fixed rate. DAI Direct Deposit Module (D3M) - Allows DAI to be minted and deposited in other crypto lending protocols on the Ethereum blockchain in exchange for a deposit/collateral token from that lending protocol.  Undertake Necessary Risk and Legal Assessments to Increase the NS-DROP Debt Ceiling to 50 Million DAI - November 28, 2022 Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary:  This Signal poll allows for the Strategic Finance Core Unit to move forward with Risk and Legal assessments on increasing the Debt Ceiling of the NS-DROP vault with the below parameters.  Adding in WSFS as the trustee, based on the Trust Indenture put together earlier this year by Christian Petersen and Eli Cohen. Increase Vault Debt Ceiling to 50 million DAI. Remove senior co-investor requirement and over-collateralization requirement Increase Junior minimum to 20% from 15% Increase Stability Fee to 4.5% from 3.5%   With current market conditions, it is reasonable to understand the risks of potentially increasing this debt ceiling. The proposed Term Sheet looks good. Company projections are reasonable, and we are pleased to view a summary of the portfolio overview. We are interested in Genesis Trading and its capacity to execute but look forward to seeing the findings of this assessment.

content.content: December Week 2 - Polls Votes  Change of Ownership of the Ambassador’s Program Multi-Sig - December 12, 2022 Dai Foundation Board Member Election Poll - December 12, 2022 Sidestream Auction Services Core Unit (SAS-001) Funding Request - December 12, 2022 Governance Communications Core Unit (COM-001) Funding Request - December 12, 2022 Ratification Poll for Pioneer DeFi-focused Language Dataset for the Benefit of Risk Modelling & Governance Communication (MIP55c3-SP11) - December 12, 2022   Change of Ownership of the Ambassador’s Program Multi-Sig - December 12, 2022 Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary: There is a needed Change in ownership of the Multi-Sig for the Ambassador Program. The current owner indicated her desire to stand aside from her position and duties with the program due to personal reasons. First off, we thank you @kat for everything you have done and contributed. This is an operational vote that we agree with. Thank you for stepping up @Sebix. You will do great.  Ratification Poll for Pioneer DeFi-focused Language Dataset for the Benefit of Risk Modelling & Governance Communication (MIP55c3-SP11) - December 12, 2022 Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary: The request is to fund the aggregation of a DeFi-specific data set for Risk modeling. The data will be used to tune LLMs and should help drive more insightful decision-making for the CU. Coming from a Data modeling background, I am interested in exploring the aggregation of this data and look forward to reading about the progression of this endeavor.  Dai Foundation Board Member Election Poll - December 12, 2022 Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Abstain Summary: With the establishment of the Dai Foundation Core Unit, the Dai Foundation pledged to appoint MakerDAO members to its board. Earlier this year the organization reached out for potential candidates. The two choices were Daimon-Law and OxbocaJ. Both are very qualified candidates. Please see the candidate statements below: Daimon-Law: candidate statement here. OxbocaJ: candidate statement here. Ultimately, we cannot vouch for either candidate directly (among other things) and choose to recuse ourselves/abstain from the vote. We are confident in the ability of more experienced delegates to identify and select the correct candidates.  Sidestream Auction Services Core Unit (SAS-001) Funding Request - December 12, 2022 Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary:  This is a poll to ask for the consent of recognized delegates to finance the operations of SAS CU for the months of December 2022, January 2023, February 2023 and March 2023 through funds in SAS Dssvest, Auditor and Operational wallet.  We support the standard operating procedures after approving a new budget for this CU.  Governance Communications Core Unit (COM-001) Funding Request - December 12, 2022 Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary: Requests spending budget for GovComms winddown for the month of january. Although we disagree with govcomms offboarding, we support the appropriate offboarding of the CU and facilitators. The spend will cover the following:  Facilitator Compensation for the month of January 2023. Service fees to AccountAble for the month of January 2023. Offboard fees to our payroll provider.

content.content: January Week 2 - Polls  Parameter Changes Proposal - PPG-OMC-001 - 5 January 2023 Request to Poll: One-time MKR Distribution to Correct CES-001 Incentive Program Shortfall Poll Notice: Confirmation of Trial DssKiln Deployment   Parameter Changes Proposal - PPG-OMC-001 - 5 January 2023 Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary: The MakerDAO Open Market Committee (OMC) is proposing changes to the MakerDAO protocol to increase revenue and accruing of COMP rewards to the MakerDAO treasury. This proposal suggests reactivating the Aave D3M with a modest debt ceiling, increasing the Compound v2 D3M debt ceiling, gradually normalizing stability fees for the WSTETH-B vault type, and increasing fees on the USDP PSM to avoid growth in an exposure. Estimates indicate that these changes would lead to a roughly 525,000 DAI increase in annual revenue for the MakerDAO treasury. Takeaway: The proposed changes take into account the current market conditions and aim to increase the platform’s utilization. Additionally, The proposal suggests gradually normalizing the stability fee on the WSTETH-B vault type to reach parity with ETH-C, aiming to drive new usage. Lastly, The 525,000 DAI increase in annual revenue for the MakerDAO treasury, would benefit the ecosystem. As always, we continue to support the critical work of the committee.  Request to Poll: One-time MKR Distribution to Correct CES-001 Incentive Program Shortfall Forum Discussion Vote Decision: Yes Summary: The Interim Collateral Engineering Services (CES) is proposing a one-time MKR distribution of 96.15 MKR to cover the deficiency in rewards for current contributors, as a result of the previous facilitator accelerating payouts to selected members before leaving. The distribution would be transferred to the CES Auditor Wallet to cover annual vesting awards for current members. Why we are voting yes: This proposal is a fair and necessary measure to align with the approved rewards program and ensure current contributors receive the expected awards. The deficiency was created by the previous facilitator’s actions and this distribution will ensure current contributors are compensated for their contributions.  Poll Notice: Confirmation of Trial DssKiln Deployment Forum Discussion Vote Decision: (1) Burn .5 million DAO worth of MKR, (2) No burn Summary: The Facilitators of the GovAlpha, Protocol Engineering, and Risk Core Units are proposing a poll to confirm whether voters still wish to proceed with the trial deployment of DssKiln, a system for burning DAI worth of MKR that was previously approved through MIP74. The poll will ask voters to select from options including burning 0.5, 1, 2, or 3 million DAI worth of MKR or abstaining. The poll aims to gauge voter sentiment before proceeding with an executive vote and considers the passage of time since initial approval, changes in market sentiment and DAO priorities, and the fall in MKR price. Other information: MIP74, or the “Permissionless Open Market Operations” proposal, is a suggestion by the MakerDAO community to establish a system that allows anyone to mint or burn DAI without the need for permission from the MakerDAO community. This will be achieved by using a smart contract called the “Permissionless OMO engine” or POLE. This smart contract will determine the collateralization ratio at which minting and burning occur based on DAI’s supply and demand in the open market. This approach is intended to assist in stabilizing the DAI/USD price by adjusting the monetary supply in response to market forces, making it more responsive and decentralized. It’s important to note that the MIP74 proposal is considered experimental, and its implementation is more of a trial than a permanent solution. Takaway: This option reduces the potential risk and impact on the MKR token economy while still allowing for the trial deployment to proceed and gather valuable data on the effectiveness of burning MKR to stabilize the DAI peg. Additionally, by reducing the amount of MKR burned, it preserves more of the MKR token supply for future use.

content.content: January Week 2 - Polls (2/2)  MIP4c2-SP31: MIP63 Maker Keeper Network Amendment Ratification Poll for Defense Fund Ratification Poll for Onboard PSM USDC to Yearn to earn Yield Ratification Poll for Declaration of Intent to Develop a Comprehensive On-chain Monitoring Solution for RWA Vaults Ratification Poll for Onboard-Amend Keeper Network - Chainlink Automation Ratification Poll for Special Purpose Fund for developing Proof-of-Performance for Viridian Cluster Ratification Poll for Commercial Risk and Legal Domain Work to Support SF-001 Expanded Mandate Related to RWAs Ratification Poll for Protocol DAI Transfer to Fund IS-001 from Dec 2022 to May 2023 Ratification Poll for Requesting Protocol DAI Transfer to fund TechOps CU for February 2023 Ratification Poll for Core Unit Offboarding Ratification Poll for Remove MIP14c4 Ratification Poll for Obsolete MIP Removal Ratification Poll for MIP14 Repeal Ratification Poll for Amend MIP51 to Remove MIP51c4 Ratification Poll for Amend MIP61 to tighten up Recognized Delegate Participation Metrics   MIP4c2-SP31: MIP63 Maker Keeper Network Amendment Forum Discussion Vote: Yes Summary: This proposal is a modification to the MIP63 Maker Keeper Network Amendment, which ran a successful beta test. The proposal aims to incorporate learnings from the beta test by more strictly defining payment processes, buffer reporting, and changing some parameters. Why we are voting Yes: This proposal is a critical step in improving the MIP63 Maker Keeper Network Amendment, which has already demonstrated success in its beta test. The changes proposed in this amendment will help refine and optimize the system, making it more efficient and effective. Additionally, the explicit stream duration and the ability for the Sequencer to set custom windows per network will provide greater flexibility and control over the system.  Ratification Poll for Defense Fund (MIP55c3-SP14) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: Yes Summary: This proposal is for creating a Defense Fund, which will be used to reimburse legal defense expenses for active participants of MakerDAO in case they are the target of legal or regulatory action. The fund will initially cover Recognized Delegates, Core Unit Facilitators, Core Unit permanent contributors, and Active MKR holders. The proposal also includes a plan for managing claims and payouts, which an external technical committee will oversee, and a minimum capital requirement for the fund. Why we are voting Yes: This proposal is important for protecting active participants of MakerDAO from potential legal risks associated with the novel organizational structure of DAOs. The Defense Fund will serve as a contingency budget to cover legal defense expenses, providing a safety net for those actively involved in the MakerDAO ecosystem. The plan for managing claims and payouts is well thought out, and the inclusion of insurance and risk management experts will ensure that the fund is managed responsibly and effectively.  Ratification Poll for Onboard PSM USDC to Yearn to earn Yield (MIP92) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: Yes Summary: MIP92 proposes onboarding $100M of PSM USDC into a bespoke non-custodial Yearn vault. Yearn vaults are risk-adjusted and transparent, and the proposed strategies for the bespoke vault are flexible. Assigned Yearn contributors will work closely with the relevant Maker Core Units as proposed in MIP92c5. Security measures: Yearn is an established and reputable organization known for its safety and transparency. Using on-chain vaults will empower the Maker community to audit the location and amounts of deposited assets continually. Yearn’s risk-adjusted vaults are battle-tested and have handled an all-time high of $6.4 billion with no loss of funds. Proposed strategies: The composition of the bespoke vault is flexible, and Yearn contributors in coordination with the relevant Maker Core Units will propose strategies. Maintenance and Upkeep: Yearn is maintained by a team of full-time contributors and is governed by the YFI token. Why we are voting Yes: This is a significant step in generating a yield on idle USDC while ensuring safety and transparency. Yearn is uniquely positioned to offer Maker yield-generation opportunities, and its reputation and track record in DeFi make it a reliable choice. Yearn aligns with Maker’s safety-first strategy, and using its vaults will further validate the case for decentralized finance where safety and transparency matter most. Additionally, the proposed strategies for the bespoke vault are flexible, allowing for adaptability to market conditions and maximizing returns for MakerDAO. Overall, this proposal is a great opportunity for MakerDAO to benefit from Yearn’s expertise and track record in yield generation and risk management.  Ratification Poll for Declaration of Intent to Develop a Comprehensive On-chain Monitoring Solution for RWA Vaults (MIP13c3-SP13) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: Yes Summary: MIP13c3-SP13 proposal is intended to pick a RWA on-chain monitoring solution by electing to fund a proposed SPF by an external solution provider. The proposer should demonstrate the ability and the credentials that they can develop a trustworthy and transparent solution to RWA monitoring. Why we are voting Yes: The proposal aims to develop maximum transparency around the scaling up of RWA vaults for yield and diversification, by picking an external solution provider that can develop a trustworthy and transparent solution for monitoring RWA vaults for violations of covenants or reporting obligations.  Ratification Poll for Onboard-Amend Keeper Network - Chainlink Automation (MIP63c4-SP5) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: Yes Summary: MIP63c4-SP5 proposes adding Chainlink Automation to MakerDAO’s third-party Keeper Network to improve the protocol’s security and uptime guarantees. A Chainlink Automation contract test run has been conducted on the Ethereum mainnet and has completed 35 automation jobs without issue. The budget parameters are the same as other Keeper network participants, and any excess DAI beyond the maximum will be returned to the surplus buffer. Why we are voting Yes: The proposal aims to improve the Maker protocol’s efficiency, security, and decentralization by adding Chainlink Automation to the Keeper Network. The test run of the contract has been successful, and the budget and other parameters are in line with other Keeper network participants. The integration of Chainlink Automation is expected to impact the protocol’s performance at a low cost positively.  Ratification Poll for Special Purpose Fund for developing Proof-of-Performance for Viridian Cluster (MIP55c3-SP13) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: No Summary: This MIP proposes a Special Purpose Fund (SPF) of 500,000 DAI to fund a set of RWA projects to be undertaken by the Viridian Cluster within the 6 months of Jan 2023 - Jun 2023. The projects include MIP65, MIP81, MIP88 and potentially others brought for evaluation to the community, where Monetalis will act as Arranger. The SPF will allow Maker to continue key RWA projects in the interim period until MetaDAOs can be launched and allows the Maker Community to evaluate the work of the Viridian Cluster ahead of a potential adoption of the cluster to a Protector MetaDAO. Why we are voting No: Unclear on future viability. Happy to revisit after the endgame is in a more advanced position.  Ratification Poll for Commercial Risk and Legal Domain Work to Support SF-001 Expanded Mandate Related to RWAs (MIP55c3-SP12) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: Yes Summary: This MIP proposes creating a special purpose fund (SPF) of 209k DAI to support the expanded mandate of SF-001 regarding RWAs. The fund will be used to onboard a structured finance consultant and legal counsel to perform commercial and legal risk analysis on RWAs, monitor and create reporting for existing RWA vaults, and collaborate with the community on the design of the RWA Council. Why we are voting Yes: This SPF is important as it will provide funding for the commercial and legal risk analysis of RWAs, which is crucial for protecting Maker Core and DAI holders as the protocol navigates the End Game Plan.  Ratification Poll for Protocol DAI Transfer to Fund IS-001 from Dec 2022 to May 2023 (MIP14c2-SP2) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: Yes Summary: This MIP proposes a protocol DAI transfer of 43,560 DAI to fund the Immunefi Security Core Unit (ISCU) from December 2022 to May 2023. The ISCU team and services will be sustained through May, and they anticipate dissolving as a Core Unit and becoming an EndGame ecosystem actor. Why we are voting Yes: The proposed transfer is well below the DAI Transfer Ceiling (250,000 DAI) and is taken from the current surplus. The ISCU has been maintaining and providing security services to the MakerDAO ecosystem. The funding will support the team and services to continue the work until May 2023, after which they plan to dissolve as a Core Unit and become an EndGame ecosystem actor.  Ratification Poll for Requesting Protocol DAI Transfer to fund TechOps CU for February 2023 (MIP14c2-SP1) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: Yes Summary: This MIP proposes a transfer of 138,894 DAI to fund TechOps CU for February 2023. The team, critical infrastructure, tools, and services will be sustained through this month, and a second MIP14 sub-proposal will be posted for the month of March. Why we are voting Yes: The community rejected the TechOps CU’s original 2023 budget for several reasons, including being too high and not giving Bear market vote options. They have taken this feedback onboard and have revised their new budget significantly, which will be up for voting in March 2023. Due to the quarterly budgeting cycle, they are left without funding for February and March 2023, which will cover their expenses for February. Any excess funds will be promptly returned to the protocol.  Ratification Poll for Core Unit Offboarding (COM-001) (MIP39c3-SP7) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: 60.7K / 100% | 60.7K / 80% Summary: This MIP is a proposal to offboard the GovComms Core Unit and provide the contributors with a “golden parachute” compensation and retroactive benefits. The goal is to support the transition, formalize the team’s status, and provide compensation. The proposal includes a one-time expense of 60,700 DAI to cover the offboarding costs. Why we are voting Yes: This proposal includes a one-time expense of 60,700 DAI to cover the offboarding expenses of the GovComms Core Unit. This amount is necessary to provide a “golden parachute” compensation and retroactive benefits to the contributors, which is appropriate as they have been working on the project and their work will be transitioned or closed by the end of December. The 100% multiplier will ensure sufficient funds to cover all necessary expenses. Thank you for everything govcoms. We look forward to working with you again!  Ratification Poll for Remove MIP14c4 (Protocol DAI Transfer Ceiling) (MIP4c2-SP32) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: Yes Summary: The MIP4c2-SP32 proposal aims to remove the 250,000 DAI cap on the total amount of DAI that can be distributed through MIP14, known as the Protocol DAI Transfer. The proposal is motivated by the anticipation of an increase in funding requests through MIP14 and MIP55 as the MakerDAO system transitions to the Endgame state. Why we are voting Yes: Removing the cap would prevent a failure state where the sum of all fund requests in a Governance Cycle through MIP14 would exceed the ceiling and would not allow for the distribution of Maker Governance-approved funds promptly. Additionally, the remaining content of MIP14 is considered appropriate, and therefore, there is no need to replace the entire MIP.  Ratification Poll for Obsolete MIP Removal (MIP23, MIP28) (MIP4c4-SP3) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: Yes Summary: The MIP4c4-SP3 proposal aims to remove MIP23 and MIP28, passed in 2020. The motivation for this proposal is that the Domain framework, which these MIPs are a part of, has been superseded by the Core Unit Framework, and the transition from the former to the latter is complete, making these MIPs no longer necessary. Why we are voting Yes: Removing these MIPs would keep MakerDAO’s MIPS Framework slim and reflective of the system’s current state. Additionally, MIP23 and MIP28 are no longer serving any purpose. They are considered obsolete, so it’s beneficial to mark them as such and remove them to maintain the clarity and efficiency of the framework.  Ratification Poll for MIP14 Repeal (MIP4c4-SP2) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: No Summary: This MIP proposes repealing MIP14, which outlines a generic procedure for DAI to be sent from the protocol to an Ethereum address. The MIP is being proposed to simplify the growing body of DAO governance processes and policies. As MIP14 does not appear to have ever been utilized, the transfer of DAI for several purposes has typically been authorized through whatever governance action authorizes the activity financed by that transfer. Why we are voting No: Future ability to fund.  Ratification Poll for Amend MIP51 to Remove MIP51c4 (Calendar Exceptions) (MIP4c2-SP28) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: No Summary: This MIP is proposing an amendment to MIP51 by removing the calendar exception found in MIP51c4. The December exception was put in place when there were significant problems with getting anything done in the Maker on-chain governance. However, with the current delegate system in place, these problems have been resolved, and the December exception is no longer needed to govern the protocol without a break. Why we are voting No: While we understand the spirit of this proposal. We believe that structure around complex governance structures is OK. The December gap allows participants and delegates to reflect on the protocol and work on in-depth topics/problems in preparation for January.  Ratification Poll for Amend MIP61 to tighten up Recognized Delegate Participation Metrics (MIP4c2-SP29) - January 9, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: Approve both Summary: This MIP proposes an amendment to MIP61 that aims to change two aspects of the Recognized Delegate Compensation MIP. The first change is that recognized delegates will not be eligible for compensation if they fail to meet a threshold of non-abstaining votes. The second change is that participation in executive votes should have a higher weight and stricter requirements when compared to on-chain polls. Why we are voting Yes: The proposal will improve the accountability and responsibility of Recognized Delegates by setting a threshold for non-abstaining votes and making executive votes more critical. This will ensure that Recognized Delegates actively participate in the governance process and consider the security and operational issues surrounding Executive Votes.

content.content: January Week 2 - Executive Vote (2/2)  Core Unit Budget Streams, MKR Vesting, Recognized Delegate Compensation - January 11, 2023 Summary: This executive proposal outlines the allocation of DAI and MKR to different core units and delegates compensation for December. If the proposal passes, DAI budget streams will be initiated for the Development & UX Core Unit (DUX-001) and the Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling Core Unit (SES-001), MKR vesting transfers will be made to the Deco Fixed Rate Core Unit (DECO-001), the Risk Core Unit (RISK-001) and the Oracles Core Unit (ORA-001), and a MKR vesting stream will be initiated for the Protocol Engineering Core Unit (PE-001). Additionally, recognized delegate compensation totaling 108,690 DAI will be made to various addresses. Why we are voting Yes: As always, we support the forward progression and execution of business priorities.

content.content: Adjust the GUSD PSM Debt Ceiling - January 16, 2023 Decrease GUSD PSM Fee Out (tout) - January 16, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote:  1st option reduce debt ceiling to 100M, Lower to 0 Lower GUSD tout  Summary: Two polls are being proposed regarding a partnership between MakerDAO and Gemini. The first poll asks if the community supports changing the PSM tout parameter. The fee-out-tout parameter is the percentage fee applied when trading DAI into the PSM in exchange for the collateral asset. The second poll is asking if the debt ceiling parameter should also be changed. Why we are voting to reduce the GUSD tout Lowering the tout will incentive the swapping of DAI for the underlying collateral. This is a natural methodology to lower GUSD risk or be prepared to act further. Why we are voting to reduce to 100 million: Maintaining a similar theme of risk mitigation. Risk is important to manage in unknown times. Although this is a good source of income and is generally trusted by the protocol, lowering the debt ceiling lowers risk in the case of unimaginable scenarios. Additionally, there is a concern that market confidence and reputation/trust deteriorate in Gemini. Although this is FUD right now, this should be looked at seriously. Note. We support Gemini and the general openness of GUSD. We do not have evidence of any failures. However, we believe general risk mitigation is not bad in any scenario.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: January Week 4 - Polls  Offboarding Parameters for USDC-A, USDP-A, and GUSD-A - January 23, 2023 Adjusting Dust Parameter    Offboarding Parameters for USDC-A, USDP-A, and GUSD-A - January 23, 2023 Forum Discussion Vote: Yes Summary: The proposal is to offboard fiat stablecoin vaults [USDC-A, USDP-A, GUSD-A] by increasing the liquidation ratio to 1500%. It explains that these vault types no longer serve many purposes in the protocol since the PSM was established and that the liquidity of these vaults will likely increase the reserves. It also notes that the remaining vault positions can be seen as having theoretical value for their owners but that some are abandoned, and liquidation is the only way to remove them from the system. Why we are voting yes: We support the standard operations of the DAO,  it should be noted that sound accounting practices take precedence within the protocol.   Adjusting Dust Parameter Forum Discussion Vote: Yes Summary: The proposal is to reduce the minimum debt required to open a vault in the Maker protocol, known as the “dust parameter.” This would make vaults more accessible for smaller users, but also carries some risk of negative user experience if gas prices increase in the future. Why we are voting for a broad reduction: A broad reduction would allow more users to access vaults and make the protocol more inclusive. This would also increase the potential utility of small vaults, as the cost of using them has decreased. Why we are voting for a limited reduction: A limited reduction would still increase accessibility for smaller users and maintain a buffer against risk in case gas prices increase. This would be a more cautious approach to reducing dust parameters and would balance accessibility with risk management. Both options are to reflect and in line with market conditions.

content.content: February Week 3 Polls  Included Poll  Implement a Feature to Refund People who Lost Money Sending Dai to the Dai Contract Address MIP62 to Allow for Changing Communication Responsibilities Ratification Poll for Amend Interim Facilitator Appointment Process Ratification Poll for $100M of Cogent Bank Loan Participations    Polls Link: Implement a Feature to Refund People who Lost Money Sending Dai to the Dai Contract Address Forum: Link Vote: Yes Summary: The proposal suggests that users who have mistakenly transferred DAI to the DAI contract address should be able to recover their lost funds. When DAI is transferred to the DAI contract address, it is destroyed, and there is no way to retrieve the lost funds. The proposal recommends that DAI regarded as permanently destroyed be issued to the transferrer through the mint function in the smart contract. Maker could also support users by imposing a 10% penalty to prevent abuse. Takeaway: Accidentally losing funds by transferring DAI to the DAI contract address can be a frustrating and costly experience for users. The proposed MIP addresses this issue by allowing users to recover their lost funds. Furthermore, the proposal includes measures to prevent abuse and ensure the sustainability of the DAI ecosystem. As such, we voted Yes on this proposal. Link: MIP62 to Allow for Changing Communication Responsibilities Forum: Link Vote: Yes Summary: This amendment aims to replace GovComms as the responsible party for communicating offboarding through MIP62 and to prevent the need for a token vote in the future. It modifies MIP62c2 and MIP62c3 and adds a new component, MIP62c5. The amendment replaces references to GovComms with a Communication Coordinator defined in MIP62c5, with GovAlpha as the new coordinator. The amendment also allows MIP Editors to modify MIP62c5 without a governance vote under certain conditions and requires public communication of any modifications. Takeaway: The proposed amendment seeks to enhance the MIP governance process by replacing GovComms with a more flexible Communication Coordinator defined in MIP62c5. It also streamlines the process of modifying MIP62c5 to ensure that the communication role can be fulfilled effectively, even if the previous coordinator is unwilling or unable to do so. Furthermore, the requirement for public communication of any modifications to MIP62c5 increases transparency and accountability in the governance process. Overall, this amendment improves the governance framework and makes it more resilient to future challenges. Link: Ratification Poll for Amend Interim Facilitator Appointment Process Forum: Link Vote: Yes Summary: The existing Interim Facilitator process has been deemed less than ideal, with issues such as lack of speedy resolution and inflexibility. Therefore, changes have been proposed to make the process more effective. The proposed changes include limiting the number of Interim Facilitators to one, specifying the maximum time an Interim Facilitator can serve, and making them responsible for finding a permanent replacement. The appointment process has also been modified to give Governance Facilitators more power to modify the process, to allow voluntary offboarding Facilitators to nominate an Interim Facilitator, and to enable other Core Units to override the outgoing Facilitator if necessary. Several edge cases are also detailed in the MIP to cover likely scenarios, and Governance Facilitators are explicitly empowered to resolve unanticipated edge cases. This change reduces Maker Governance’s input in Interim Facilitator selection in favor of speed and maintaining continuity. Takeaway: The changes reduce Maker Governance’s input in Interim Facilitator selection, which is expected to result in faster resolution times and better continuity. Link: Ratification Poll for $100M of Cogent Bank Loan Participations Forum: Link Vote: Yes Summary: Cogent Bank, an FDIC-regulated bank, has proposed participating in MakerDAO’s existing RWA Master Participation Trust with $100M of loans using the same Participation Agreement with the same terms as MakerDAO’s deal with Huntingdon Valley Bank. The proposal is an opportunity for MakerDAO to reinforce its strategic value for community banks and doubles Cogent’s capacity to originate loans to existing and new customers. Takeaway: The Huntingdon Valley Bank deal’s success helped validate MakerDAO’s approach to RWAs. It attracted the attention of other banks like Cogent Bank, which has proposed to participate with $100M in loans using the same participation agreement and terms as the Huntingdon Valley Bank deal.

Link:  Decrease the RETH-A Dust Parameter - March 6, 2023 Forum: Link Vote: Yes Summary: Maker recently adjusted the dust parameters for several large-cap vault types, and now they are proposing to reduce the RETH-A dust parameter from 15,000 DAI to 7,500 DAI. This will align the RETH-A dust parameter with similar vault types and make it more accessible for smaller users. Why we voted Yes: The proposed change will increase usage. It will provide more economic benefits for 7,500 DAI debt RETH-A vaults to repay, instead of allowing their position to liquidate. Additionally, the reduced dust parameter aligns RETH-A with similar vault types, making it more accessible for smaller users. Key Takeaway: Maker is constantly reviewing and adjusting its parameters to ensure the safety and accessibility of its platform. The proposed change to the RETH-A dust parameter is a positive step in this direction, as it will make the platform more accessible to smaller users while still protecting Maker from potential risks.

content.content: March Week 2 - Executive  Emergency Proposal: Risk and Governance Parameter Changes (11 March 2023)    Emergency Proposal: Risk and Governance Parameter Changes (11 March 2023)  Discussion: Link Vote: Yes Summary: MakerDAO’s Risk-Core-Unit requested an emergency governance proposal to mitigate risks to the protocol. The proposed actions aim to limit Maker’s exposure to potentially impaired stablecoins and other risky collaterals while maintaining enough liquidity to prevent DAI from trading significantly above $1 if conditions change. Why we voted yes: The proposed changes aim to reduce Maker’s exposure to potential bank failures and limit potential losses. The changes also aim to prevent excessive dumping of USDC into the PSM and limit arbitrage opportunities to drain stronger USDP collateral from the protocol. Key takeaways: The proposed changes aim to reduce debt ceilings for collaterals containing USDC to 0, reduce the gap parameter for PSM-USDC-A from 950 million DAI to 250 million DAI, reduce the gap parameter for PSM-GUSD-A from 50 million to 10 million DAI, increase the maximum debt ceiling line for PSM-USDP-A to 1 billion from 450 million DAI, set the bar to 0 for Compound v2 D3M, and reduce the GSM delay to 16 hours. These changes aim to limit Maker’s exposure to potential bank failures and prevent significant losses.

content.content: Name: pvl Delegate Address: 0xD9D00c42BeD99A6D3a0F2902c640BCCCEECF6C29 Discourse: @pvl Discord: @pvl#3939 (for now mainly active in the Endgame Discord) Bird’s-eye view: Miro | Online Whiteboard for Visual Collaboration Read the Ethereum Whitepaper in 2015. Was involved with the Tezos community in its early days. Did some UX work for Radar Relay. Served on the Tribe a.k.a. Fei DAO Optimistic Approval multisig committee, which successfully served as a testbed before Tribe’s transition to Orca Pod-based Liquid governance in May '22. During its 8-month run OA reviewed and voted on 130+ actions, including reviewing the input of the security audit vendor to verify the work done before wiring payment. Currently on the Gro protocol Treasury management committee with a mandate to execute on pre-agreed (‘whitelisted’) treasury deployments, run due diligence and negotiations, submit proposals to the DAO for voting, and instruct the DAO multisig to act on those instructions. The Platform Bringing in background in machine learning, TradFi financial consulting and some DeFi I recognise as equally important for Maker’s foreseeable future nurturing DAO culture conducive to building trust of current and potential Maker products users while integrating into the DAO practice   web3-native intelligence for protocol stewardship, collateral onboarding and Treasury management;   provably optimal infrastructure funding mechanisms;   web3-native community support tools   thus fulfilling the protocol’s mission as a provider of decentralised financial products.  Ironically Maker, as DeFi at large, turns out to be in the trust business. It’s just that trust here concerns DAO’s technical and organisational reliability, a stablecoin being a trust-driven financial vehicle. You use DAI as a store of value, a medium of exchange because you’re confident about the technical and cultural sustainability of MakerDAO, its ability to build and maintain stability of its products. Realistically retail users don’t read Github or Discourse — they just have a certain subjective attitude towards the organisation, its products and its prospects. As shown by a16z cofounder Ben Horowitz in his books  “What you do is who you are”, and “The hard thing about hard things” organisation’s culture codified in its leaders’ actions is a crucial ingredient in the whole endeavour’s success or failure. For example, there’s a direct link between a leader’s arrogance and negligence on the ground level. People learn what’s considered admissible in the organisation from a leader’s behaviour patterns. Thus, a leader’s hubris can well translate into subpar software quality or security breaches. Delegates, as MKR holder’s agents, serve here as a mechanism of checks and balances preventing such a course of actions. As a brief reference here is a brief interview of Ben Horowitz discussing ways of handling culture and crisis at places like Facebook, WeWork and Boeing (the B737 MAX crisis):       With DeFi gradually coming of age MakerDAO must learn to build and maintain user trust in Maker’s products beyond the enthusiast user base. As the industry is deeply entangled, DAO members should have a clear and profound understanding of DeFi dynamics at large. At the moment there’s little understanding in the industry about under-the-hood economics of even major platforms, let alone emerging ones (which comprise the majority). Basically when we say that e.g. Aave is mature we imply that judging from its track record we can assume that it’s highly stable. The subprime mortgage crisis of '08 once again reminded everybody that there is no such thing as stable by default and too mature to fail — thanks to miscalculated risks of structured products on the balance Lehman Brothers, a major Wall St. bank with a 170-year history, went bust. And AIG survived only thanks to the Fed bailout worth $200B (the scale of risk miscalculation!). The whole entangled industry was on the verge of collapse. Without web3-native, not translated from TradFi, tools for insight there’s a good chance that we’re heading towards a crisis of (relatively) similar scale in DeFi caused by underestimated or miscalculated risks. Meanwhile, DeFi doesn’t have the Fed to bail it out. Maker as any web3 protocol is an evolving shared narrative: it lives simultaneously in two domains open for exploration: onchain transactions and broader user&contributor community interactions. They inform and impact each other in both directions in a myriad of ways creating a bipartite heterogenous living organism. To comprehend and be able to predict this organism means to be able to model and predict evolution of its two integral parts in a coherent, unified way. My thoughts and proposals on this:     Towards web3-native intelligence: tools for protocol comprehension and stewardship Proposal Ideas       I’m working on web3/DeFi-native modelling and am seeking funding + colab opportunities for the next stage. Wanted to gauge community mood regarding match of interests before submitting formal applications.   TL;DR A web3 protocol is an evolving shared narrative: it lives simultaneously in two domains open for exploration, onchain transactions and community interactions. They inform and impact each other in both directions in a myriad of ways creating a bipartite heterogenous living organism. To …      To prove its organisation’s trustworthy sustainability, MakerDAO must learn to fund its infrastructure development and maintenance initiatives in the most efficient, optimal way. The key task that is up for recurrent solutions within MakerDAO is finding consensus over alternative policy priorities and allocating limited resources (financial and non-financial) accordingly. In other words bridging the discrepancy in perceived subjective value of respective competing policy venues, ideally by measuring it and mapping these subjective values to respective allocations in an optimal Maker’s interests-wise way. One can foresee that without a systematic approach this problem will only exacerbate with the protocol growing more complex with consequent increasing complexity of the protocol’s infrastructure and range of contributing efforts. Since Maker, as any decentralised fat protocol, is open infrastructure, Maker infrastructure funding is essentially a problem of optimal allocation of limited resources towards public goods. There is a provably optimal way to do it. My thoughts and proposals on this:     DeCap + Quadratic Funding: augmenting the EndGame. Optimal infrastructure funding mechanism for MakerDAO Governance       I’ve been thinking about @rune 's Endgame proposal.  The key task that is up for recurrent solutions within MakerDAO is finding consensus over alternative policy priorities and allocating limited resources (financial and non-financial) accordingly. In other words bridging the discrepancy in perceived subjective value of respective competing policy venues, ideally by measuring it and mapping these subjective values to respective allocations in an optimal Maker’s interests-wise way. One can forese…      Discord and Discourse were not devised with web3 use cases in mind and hence limit the DAO. This community could again be a trailblazer for the industry in adopting web3-native community support platforms. Geneva integrates token-gated rooms and wallet connect on top of chat rooms, forum rooms, audio rooms, video rooms, and broadcast rooms in one platform with all standard features. They promise in the near future more web3-native stuff around tokenomics-based data feeds enabling turning networks into economies. Skiff: IPFS-based Docs + Drive + Mail with wallet connect.  As a long-term topic I’d encourage discussing that given escalating USD inflation maybe it’d be wise for Maker to work on stable products pegged to something different than 1 fiat currency, e.g. a basket of commodities. A similar TradFi experiment with IMF Special Drawing Rights has already happened. It might actually become Maker’s competitive edge. Potential conflicts of interest Other than my involvement with Gro I don’t have any investments or incentives that should impact my role as a delegate at the current time. Waiver of liability I have read and pledge to follow the Recognized Delegate Code of Conduct. I will do my best to act in Maker’s interests. I will maintain communication regarding my stance on the various issues that are voted on. By delegating to me you acknowledge and agree that @pvl will not be held liable for any damages caused by my participation in the Maker Protocol or because of any votes cast or not cast while acting as a delegate.

content.content: Tactical Re-allocation Process for Budget Adjustments - August 1, 2022 Any budgeting process inevitably ends up somewhere on the spectrum between full automation, decisions are computable functions of quantitive KPIs, and purely manual approach, decisions are results of informal discussions and agreements. You can’t avoid finding a compromise between unfair and unrealistic KPIs, which always don’t take into account the reality of life, and subjective, opinionated human decisions. Inevitably there needs to be a layer between MKR holders and CUs for oversight and stewardship. Direct democracy works only under a very rigid scaffold of conditions. For now delegates have no codified power for oversight, but somebody has to do it in the interests of MKR holders. Maker could go forward with designing and implementing a bespoke structure(s) with this mandate. Unfortunately, the protocol is losing money as we are debating the issue. The proposal is an opportunity to sculpture such structure on the go. It will be an emergent rather than planned process. There’s nobody in the Maker community other than delegates who could jumpstart this process of finding an optimal design for the oversight and stewardship body by working on a better budgeting process simultaneously tackling the problem of bringing the protocol to the break even point. Hence support of tactical reallocation.

content.content: This topic was automatically closed 91 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.

CodeKnight Key Info Delegate Address: 0xE89f973A19Cd76C3e5e236062668e43042176638 Forum: @Codeknight Discord: @CodeKnight#2566 Email: [email protected] Core Values   Simplify the core protocol, eliminate or externalize low-value complexity. This is essential for a DAO and also creates more space in our “complexity budget” to onboard high value features.   Developing sustainable, decentralized systems. I fully support reaching an end game where the protocol can run itself with simple oversight.   Ensure the interest Maker holders are represented. I welcome communication with all holders.   Delegate Statement As a delegate working under Wallfacer Labs, my goal is to turn Maker into a trillion-dollar entity that is easy to understand and decentralized. I am committed to helping grow Maker into a sustainable, profitable system that provides DAI as an accessible, permissionless stablecoin. To do this, I will emphasize reducing complexity and building easy to evaluate processes, to ensure that both delegates and Maker holders can understand the protocol and it’s governance. Simplicity is essential to decentralization, both to avoid hidden centralization points and to identify potential weaknesses and waste. I am a believer in incremental improvement, so I am just as interested in little ideas to make things run more smoothly as big sweeping changes. I will support proposals that provide strong risk-adjusted returns, with clear metrics to evaluate their success. I will object to proposals with unjustifiably high costs or that don’t fit into the wider Maker ecosystem and it’s budget. As a delegate, I commit to providing honesty, transparency and openness to both Maker holders and the community. About Wallfacer Wallfacer Labs is a crypto research and development company. We build and govern crypto protocols. Wallfacer employs a range of smart contract development and governance experts, allowing us to make informed decisions on all aspects of the protocol. Disclosures I have positions in Eth, MKR and TRU, and work under Wallfacer Labs. I will abstain on votes where a conflict of interest may occur. Waiver of Liability By delegating to me, you acknowledge and agree that I participate on a best efforts basis and will not be liable for any form of damages related to my participation in the Maker Protocol or MakerDAO.

content.content: Welcome, I love the framing of a complexity budget.

Exciting to see ever more governance participation. @CodeKnight I seem to remember for some reason that you are a core unit contributor, but I may have easily misunderstood that. Can you confirm that you’re not? Else it should probably be listed as a potential conflict of interest.
